(3 comments)

Patch Set 31:

(2 comments)

The patch subject needs to identify the affected subsystems. This should be prefixed with `oem: ibm: pdr: `.

But further, *what* new APIs? Please try to be as specific as possible in the space available.
Done

Again, we shouldn't be starting the description with "This commit ..." as it starts to explain the *what*, not the *why*. Why are we adding these APIs? Adding public APIs to a library is an expensive thing to do in terms of maintenance and thus needs more justification than what we currently have here.
Ack
Please be specific. *Which* IBM-specific operations? And why are they IBM-specific?
Done
If you're using words like "also" in the commit message it tends to indicate that you should instead have two separate commits to deal with each individually.
Ack

Hi Pavithra,

If we're adding to the public API surface of the library the APIs really must come with unit tests. This should be doable as we're interacting with the PDR repository, which can be relatively easily synthesised (it's harder when we interact with e.g. MCTP transports and such, but certainly not impossible).

However, further to that, it's not clear to me why we've exposed some of these functions or why some of them must be OEM, and we have a another issue with range specification.

Other comments are inline.
Done
This is an operation on a PDR repository. As such the symbol name should be prefixed with `pldm_pdr_*`
Done

This doesn't look like it's anything that's IBM-specific. Why is it in an IBM OEM header?

Also the variable names should use snake_case, not camelCase.

This API will not be of any use if it's in a generic path, this API was added during IBM specific use case ( SBE error handling support). What do you suggest Andrew, should I move it to the generic path ?
Why do we need an API for this in libpldm? Are we sure this isn't something that can be open-coded in the calling code? API maintenance isn't free.
Ack, I have moved this API to be a static function in the oem-ibm path.
See the comment on the symbol name in the header.
Done
Why do we need the cast? Is the `data` member not `void *`? Do we have a strict-aliasing problem?
Ack
@Andrew, I made a mistake here the data member is not `void *` it's a `uint8_t *` so we need a cast.
`pldm_is_endpoint_range()` could just be a static function in this file such that we don't have to add to the public API, right?
yes, I did the change.
Why is this necessary? How can I be convinced we don't have an alignment violation here?

typecasting the pdr to this structure: https://github.com/openbmc/libpldm/blob/main/include/libpldm/platform.h#L502 with the additional pldm_hdr structure - https://github.com/openbmc/libpldm/blob/main/include/libpldm/platform.h#L454
Done
Is this cast necessary?
Ack
This is all getting very contorted due to the nesting, and is borderline unreadable. Can you please rearrange the code so it's not so deeply nested?
Done

The evaluation of the `if` condition is a boolean value, just like `true` and `false` are booleans. We can just return the evaluation of the condition directly.

```
return record_handle >= first_record_handle && record_handle < last_record_handle;
```

However, we again have a problem with ranges here, and by contrast to the previous case where the range was open when it should be closed, this one is half-open (when it should be closed). We must be consistent, or else users of these APIs are going to hate us.

See Rusty's API scale:

1. [How Do I Make This Hard to Misuse?](https://ozlabs.org/~rusty/index.cgi/tech/2008-03-30.html)
2. [What If I Don't Actually Like My Users?](https://ozlabs.org/~rusty/index.cgi/tech/2008-04-01.html)
Ack

But is there any reason why anyone else can't use it? I don't know why we have to constrain it this way. If people don't care about it they just don't use it. It's much more hassle to maintain stuff that's under the OEM directory.

There is no particular reason for people not to use this API. Since we added this API as part of our use case and it had a range check added, we had written it in the oem-ibm path. This API may not be very much useful for others is what we feel 😊. Will make the change as per your suggestion Andrew.
Done
There are some problems highlighted in the comments but also in TODO notes in the code. Please address both.
Done
Exposing this in the public header still has not been properly justified.

When this definition was in pdr.c, I faced this error
`openbmc/libpldm: ../src/oem/ibm/pdr.c:22:56: error: invalid use of incomplete typedef 'pldm_pdr_record'
openbmc/libpldm:    22 | const struct pldm_pdr_hdr *hdr = record->data;`

But if we could move this method -https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/libpldm/+/63615/16/src/oem/ibm/pdr.c#12
in the generic path, then I can revert the exposing of structures in public header file.
Yes, please move the function out of the oem directory into `src/pdr.c` and fix all the other fall-out from that move.
Done

I've rewritten the loop using equivalent logic to un-nest the code as I asked earlier.

I've added TODO notes throughout this function on things that you must address before we merge this code.
Ack

we have been using the same type of casting in multiple places - https://github.com/openbmc/libpldm/blob/main/src/pdr.c#L216, https://github.com/openbmc/libpldm/blob/main/src/pdr.c#L91 and this structure was defined long back. I am not sure how can we demonstrate if it is of pldm_pdr_header type.

Okay, so I've looked myself, and due to `pldm_pdr_add()` taking only a `uint8_t *data` this assumption is never type safe. People could pass any old pointer through that. At best this code just 'happens' to work and is otherwise completely unsafe. We need to fix that, but it's a long road.
sure Andrew
In x86 structures will be padded to 4-byte alignment. I didn't follow your comment.

As it turns out we can disregard the TODO because the type of `pdr` is `struct pldm_pdr_entity_association`, which is specified with `__attribute__((packed))`.

But that's nothing to do with x86, and there's shouldn't be anything in the x86 ABI that states that structures are always 4-byte aligned. It's not spelled out directly, but generally structs are aligned to the member with the strongest alignment requirements. From the [C17 draft standard (N2176)](https://files.lhmouse.com/standards/ISO%20C%20N2176.pdf), Section 6.2.8 paragraph 2:

> A fundamental alignment is a valid alignment less than or equal to `_Alignof (max_align_t)`. Fundamental alignments shall be supported by the implementation for objects of all storage durations. The alignment requirements of the following types shall be fundamental alignments:
>
> ...
>
> — all structure or union types all of whose elements have types with fundamental alignment requirements and none of whose elements have an alignment specifier specifying an alignment that is not a fundamental alignment.

And later in paragraph 5:

> Alignments have an order from weaker to stronger or stricter alignments. Stricter alignments have larger alignment values. An address that satisfies an alignment requirement also satisfies any weaker valid alignment requirement.

In 6.7.2.1 paragraph 14 states:

> Each non-bit-field member of a structure or union object is aligned in an implementation-defined manner appropriate to its type.

A less legalese overview of this is here:

http://www.catb.org/esr/structure-packing/#_structure_alignment_and_padding

And to make it concrete we can consult the platform ABIs, which specify the fundamental alignments that are supported and their impact on aggregates. Here are a couple:

* [x86_64 psABI](https://gitlab.com/x86-psABIs/x86-64-ABI)

  Aggregates and Unions
  Structures and unions assume the alignment of their most strictly aligned component. Each member is assigned to the lowest available offset with the appropriate alignment. The size of any object is always a multiple of the object‘s alignment.
  An array uses the same alignment as its elements, except that a local or global array
variable of length at least 16 bytes or a C99 variable-length array variable always has
alignment of at least 16 bytes.
  Structure and union objects can require padding to meet size and alignment constraints.
  The contents of any padding is undefined.
  
* [AARCH32 ABI](https://github.com/ARM-software/abi-aa/blob/2982a9f3b512a5bfdc9e3fea5d3b298f9165c36b/aapcs32/aapcs32.rst)

  5.3.1   Aggregates

    The alignment of an aggregate shall be the alignment of its most-aligned component.
    The size of an aggregate shall be the smallest multiple of its alignment that is sufficient to hold all of its members when they are laid out according to these rules.

In my opinion it's a curse that libpldm uses `__attribute__((packed))` absolutely everywhere in its ABI. Generally it inhibits optimisations and has the potential to make the code slower. It is also a non-standard construct (compiler-specific). I aim to remove all use of it throughout libpldm, eventually.

So we need to care about alignment: In the C17 draft standard (N2176), Annex J.2 "Undefined behaviour" lists 

> — Conversion between two pointer types produces a result that is incorrectly aligned (6.3.2.3).

From there, 6.3.2.3 paragraph 7 states

> A pointer to an object type may be converted to a pointer to a different object type. If the resulting pointer is not correctly aligned(69) for the referenced type, the behavior is undefined.

Footnote 69 states:

> In general, the concept “correctly aligned” is transitive: if a pointer to type A is correctly aligned for a pointer to type B, which in turn is correctly aligned for a pointer to type C, then a pointer to type A is correctly aligned for a pointer to type C.

We must avoid undefined behaviour, and therefore we must care about problems such as alignment.
Thank you Andrew for the detailed explanation and pointers to them 😊

There needs to be a comment here about why this cast is valid. The trick is that we can't guarantee that it is, we just have to YOLO it. Hence you need a big flashing red light of a comment here to warn people what's going on.
Done
Is this actually the behaviour that you want?
Yes, Andrew, We are looking for PDR records outside the range. So if it's inside the range we just continue to the next PDR record

In discord I said:

> let me know if it's unclear how to address those todos. A couple of them (the casts) need to turn into comments documenting why they're a valid thing to do

This is one of those casts. I've commented on the other above. These must come with comments about why they're valid.

Currently this cast is valid with respect to alignment because `struct pldm_pdr_hdr` is declared with `__attribute__((packed))`
Done

We treat pdr->children as a flexible array member. This check *must* be before we form the pointer assigned to `child` (i.e. placed immediately after line 44 and before the code currently on line 45) otherwise we will cause ourselves headaches. From Appendix J "Undefined behaviour" of N2176 (C17 draft standard):

> An attempt is made to access, or generate a pointer to just past, a flexible array member of a structure when the referenced object provides no elements for that array (6.7.2.1).

We're currently saved by the fact that the array is declared as length 1. But that means it's not formally a flexible array member, so any access beyond 0 is UB regardless. That needs to be fixed, but again it's a long road.
Ack
Hi Pavithra, thanks for adding the comments in the implementation. I have a few more concerns that need to be addressed.

We need more words here. From what you've described in the implementation the range is a "stop" range, not a "pass" range. That is, it puts a hole in the searched handle space rather than constrain the search space to the range. That really needs some discussion.
Ack
Make it clear in the description of `first_record_handle` and `last_record_handle` that they define a range that *won't* be searched.
Done
This will go away when the function is moved.
Done

Can we please put the function name here directly, instead.

"new" is implied by "add", and with the function name included it's implicit that we're modifying the API.
Done
Hi Pavithra, thanks for moving this into the generic library portion and away from the OEM bits. I have a few more comments, but one thing I'd very much like to see is some unit tests.
Update this once the commit message is fixed.
Done
Thanks. This is a better description.
Ack

Apologies in advance because I thought I mentioned this on the previous review, but clearly didn't.

Given the description I think we need to update the function name. At the moment there's no indication of using a range, or that the range is exclusive. Further, the fact that `uint16_t` is returned suggests there's no mechanism for this function to indicate a failure to find the container ID in question.

I propose:

```
int pldm_pdr_find_container_id_range_exclude(const pldm_pdr *repo,
                                             uint16_t entity_type,
                                             uint16_t entity_instance,
                                             uint32_t range_exclude_start,
                                             uint32_t range_exclude_end,
                                             uint16_t *container_id);
```
Ack
Why does this patch need this extra argument? It shouldn't have any OEM bits in it now.
Done
Need to update the function name and prototype as per previous comment.
Done

Update this to a negative errno. `return -ENOKEY;` maybe? Whatever we pick needs to be added to the doxygen comment for the return values (the return values and the conditions they are returned under must be explicitly defined, in general).
Done
See errno comment above.
Done
Andrew, I will add some unit test cases in the next patchset.

Hi Pavithra, I made a mistake with a comment regarding an error code on PS24 so I've left a comment about fixing that. But there were are couple of bigger snags, the main one being the issue of handling endianness. The current approach is error prone and needs to be fixed, so I've marked the patch as -1 for now.

Broadly though, I think this patch is very close to being something we can merge. Thanks for iterating on it with me.

> or when repo is NULL.

That sounds more like a case for `EINVAL`.

Separately, are the error values negative or positive? I'd suggest we go with negative. Whether they're negative or positive needs to be documented here.
Ack

Oh whoops, I think I lead you astray here on PS24. I think `repo == NULL` is a caller error, we should probably use `return -EINVAL` instead. But `return -ENOKEY` down below on line 425 still feels right.
Done

Okay, so this endian conversion makes me glad I asked for tests, if only to spot this problem with the API.

We must handle endian conversions inside the library's implementation. We must not expose endian concerns through the library's APIs. The library's APIs _must_ _always_ operate with values in host endianness. I've written a blog post to unpack this position:

https://amboar.github.io/notes/2023/06/19/representations-and-design-boundaries-with-endianness.html

Please move the endian conversion inside the implementation of `pldm_pdr_find_container_id_range_exclude()`.
Done
Nit: please split the comments into 2 line to avoid crossing 80-character limit.
Ack

The function says find_container_id. You are returning the containedEntityContainerID of the child as the container_id not the containerEntityContainerID. Which seems incorrect. Please correct me if I am wrong.

There can be multiple contained entities(children) and one container entity as per the Entity Association PDR.

Yes,  will change the name of the function to `pldm_pdr_find_child_container_id_range_exclude()`. 
Yes, there can be multiple contained entities but only when the instance number and entity type of the contained entity (which is unique) match we are returning the container id corresponding to that containedEntity.
I suppose we don't need to loop further if we find a match. Should we return from here?
